Award.AwardTitle: U.S. Participation in Algebraic Cycles and Moduli Conference
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for US participants at the workshop "Algebraic Cycles and Moduli" to take place June 2-8, 2016, at the Centre de Recherches Mathematiques, Universite de Montreal, Montreal, Canada. The funding will support three principal speakers, 4 regular faculty and between 9 to 14 junior participants. The workshop activities will include three to four talks each day by leading international experts, interspersed with unscheduled time to allow for discussion and collaboration. The topic of the conference is at the forefront of current research in algebraic geometry. It involves a wide range of complex techniques from geometry, analysis, and topology and has important applications in physics.

The specific purpose of the workshop is to survey the recent developments in the field of algebraic cycles and moduli, with a focus on the following topics: (1) Mumford-Tate groups and domains, (2) Torelli-type theorems and hyperk√§hler manifolds, (3) Conformal block bundles over moduli spaces of curves, (4) Normal functions, (5) Applications of the Beilinson regulator to Mahler measure and Feynman integrals. The workshop will bring together some of the leading experts in these fields, as well as a number of young researchers, who will further propel developments in these directions. More details on the conference can be found at its website: http://www.crm.umontreal.ca/2016/Cycles16/index_e.php

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

Two classical problems in algebraic geometry are to understand the moduli space of curves of a given genus, and to understand the structure of the divisors on a fixed curve modulo linear equivalence. Hodge theory provides a natural framework in which to study both questions via the Torelli theorem and the Abel–Jacobi map.

For higher dimensional varieties, the question of construction of an appropriate moduli spaces of varieties of a given type, and the study of algebraic cycles on a fixed variety remain topics of active research.  Hodge theory again plays a central role, providing an often complete local description of the moduli space (Torelli type theorems) and various refinements of the Abel–Jacobi map which give a wealth of information about algebraic cycles modulo rational equivalence.

 This grant was in support of researchers from US institutions attending the conference entitled Algebraic Cycles and Moduli, which was held at the Centre de Recherches Mathematiques in Montreal from June 2 to June 8, 2016.  The following mathematicians gave hour long research talks:

Prakash Belkale (UNC Chapel Hill)
Christopher Deninger (Universität Münster)
Charles Doran (University of Alberta)
Angela Gibney (University of Georgia)
Mark Green (UCLA)
Paul Hacking (University of Massachusetts Amherst)
Elham Izadi (University of California, San Diego)
Matilde Lalín (Université de Montréal)
Radu Laza (Stony Brook University)
James D. Lewis (University of Alberta)
Eduard Looijenga (Universiteit Utrecht)
Eyal Markman (University of Massachusetts)
Ben Moonen (Radboud University Nijmegen)
Arvind N. Nair (Tata Institute of Fundamental Research)
Alexei A. Oblomkov (University of Massachusetts)
Deepam Patel (Purdue University)
Chris Peters (Institut Fourier)
Kartik Prasanna (University of Michigan)
Colleen Robles (Duke University)
Giulia Sacca (Stony Brook University)
Sampei Usui (Osaka University)

The grant also provided partial support for 11 graduate students and postdocs attending the conference (Kenny Ascher, Dori Bejleri, Humberto Diaz, Laure Flapan, Evangelia Gazaki, Xuntao Hu, Kevin Kordek, Deepam Patel, Giulia Sacca, Tokio Sasaki, Yu Yang).

Broader Impact: The conference fostered collaboration between different groups of researchers in Hodge theory, moduli and algebraic cycles. Specifically, there were 3–4 high quality talks per day with ample time for discussion and collaboration. The conference was designed to have a strong impact on early career researchers by affording them an excellent opportunity to interact with leading experts.
